column_.text_: I come from a long lineage of proud warriors.

We had a great number of visitors at our dojo—many of them masters of their respective
disciplines.
At some point I picked up a blade of my own, and began to mimic their movements.
Back then, I enjoyed the training for what it was, valuing the journey over the destination.

That is, until I met him—the supreme swordsmaster of the Eternals... Eahta, once known as the
demon Zanba.

With a single glance, he identified all of my weaknesses. Then, with a few words, he taught me to
overcome them.

His strength was beyond captivating. I even eavesdropped on a conversation between him and my
father and discovered we were distant relatives. I was elated.
For some time he continued to train at our family dojo.

I took every opportunity I could to learn from him, following him wherever he went. I ate whenever
he ate. I committed all his mannerisms to memory.

However, with the exception of our first encounter, he never acknowledged me. After all, he
yearned for nothing more than strength—why pay heed to a weakling such as myself?
So I vowed to become stronger. I would soar so high, he'd have to see me.

I dedicated myself to training, begrudging even a single moment of respite. The blade was
everything to me.
And eventually, there was no disciple at the dojo who could come close to rivaling my skill.
That was around when he vanished.

In the blink of an eye, he was out of my life. He spoke not another word to me, nor called me by
name.

I was meditating in the forest one day when a group of travelers approached me. I didn't know
then, but they were  and the crew of the Grandcypher—and my future.

Initially, I thought they were lost and had come to ask for directions. I was only half-correct. They
were seeking guidance, but not out of the woods. They wanted to learn martial arts from me.
I shook my head. I was no master. Only a chrysalis, struggling to break free of my own shell.
I believed  was mocking me.

But that wasn't the case. I looked into 's eyes and found truth—alongside a burning
desire for strength. It felt as if I was in—his presence again.

But that wasn't the case. I looked into 's eyes and found truth—alongside a burning
desire for strength. It felt as if I was in—his presence again.

I found myself drawn to . That's why I decided to join the crew of the Grandcypher on
their journey across the skies.
I was convinced that this was the only path that could reunite me with Zanba.
One day, I encountered an adorable Harvin girl at a local market.

I'd already finished my shopping, so I decided to accompany her to a nearby café for tea and
conversation.
Upon parting, I asked for her name. She proudly introduced herself as Fif, one of the ten Eternals.
I had heard that Zanba once cared for a child of the same name.
A jealousy brewed within me, that I hadn't felt before.
Zanba had taken notice of her, yet he never once acknowledged me during our time together.
My inner peace had been shattered.
I retreated to the mountains and started my training anew.
But the more I tried to find direction, the more I realized how lost I truly was.

It was Lyria and  who brought me back. They appreciated me for who I was.
Nothing more, nothing less.

It was Lyria and  who brought me back. They appreciated me for who I was.
Nothing more, nothing less.
Perhaps I too could learn to love the living, breathing me, and not a ghost of the future.
That thought filled me with so much contentment, I was ready to give up on chasing Zanba.

But the universe works in strange ways... As soon as I was about to let go, Fif helped bring me
and Zanba together again. It was then I finally put into words how I felt.
I spoke about how I wanted him to acknowledge me, to call my name...
He listened quietly and, for what I felt was the first time, truly saw me.

But I had yet to see—and love—myself. As part of my quest for self-discovery, I crossed blades
with Zanba—no, Eahta. We fought for days.

He no longer believed I was a weakling. After our battle, we visited the teashop, and it was there
that he first addressed me by name. Never had tea and cake tasted so sweet to me...

Now, with nothing holding me back, I am free to soar toward ever greater heights with my
beloved companions on the Grandcypher.
We... No, I had failed that day at the Halewind Altar.

I had spent years training and sharpening my skills, devoted my entire life to the pursuit of
strength...
But in that moment it all amounted to nothing.

Our experiences in Zegagrande had planted a seed of doubt in my mind. Over time, it grew, dense
and wild as a jungle, choking me with a sense of helplessness like I'd never felt before.
I wasn't able to protect Lyria or .
I had found my identity as a big sister, as a guardian. But now that I had failed... who was I?

I thought about resuming my training. But I couldn't afford to isolate myself like that. What if
something were to happen while I was away?
Then, the solution came to me.

Whenever  was about to take on a dangerous mission, I would complete it first. That
way, I could train myself and protect the crew in one fell swoop!
I was too blind to see that despair had clipped my wings and chained me once again to the past.
"Are there any particularly dangerous missions available?"
Sierokarte, with her usual cheery disposition, set a list of options before me.
"Sure are! We've got a few jobs here that only a crew of your caliber could handle. In fact—"
She paused and looked at me with a quizzical expression.

"Y'know... I can't even remember the last time I saw you here by your lonesome. Don't you usually
do things as a crew?"
I told her I intended to undertake these missions alone as part of my training.
"I gotcha... The grind never ends for you, huh? Just don't push yourself too hard, ya hear?"

I nodded, only half-acknowledging Siero's words. After deciding upon a venture, I chartered a
small carrier vessel which would take me to a nearby island.

As the ship was tossed about the turbulent winds, I closed my eyes and looked for peace within.
This is for their sake, as well as mine.

According to Siero, the threat should be somewhere around
here...
I sense great evil... Just a little farther!
You... You, I know! This is revenge for Mad Beat!
Shall we test which is stronger? Your shield or my blade.
Groooough! Draph, KILL!
Such malice... You cannot be allowed to live.
Finish heeeerrr!
Your anger is no match for mine.
I can see how this battle will end...
It ends... with your death!
Ngh... Grooogh...
You bring nothing to the skies but suffering. Perish!
Worthless...
But it's not over yet.
I will not rest while evil runs free.
"Do you not have anything more dangerous?"

I made quick work of the mission and returned at once to Siero. She seemed taken aback when I
demanded more work, but I was determined.
If someone had to risk their life... Better me than .

The crew didn't have to know. They would be kept free from worry and danger, while I grew
stronger.

I was so absorbed in my thoughts, I'd failed to notice how Siero's eyes grew ever more clouded
with worry.
I continued to take one treacherous job after another.
If you want someone safe, then keep them from entering the tiger's den. It's as simple as that.
"Are you really sure you're up for another one, Narmaya?"
Siero worried for me. But there was no turning back now.
My labor had bore fruit.

The rest of the crew was beginning to look healthier, better rested. They returned earlier from
missions, bearing fewer injuries.

"I appreciate the concern, Siero, but the path to strength is long and narrow. And I must continue
down this path... for all of their sakes!"
I was fixated on protecting my loved ones—they were all I could see.
If they were safe, then nothing else mattered.
That thought alone was enough to steel my resolution.

On days without work, I would meditate on the deck of the Grandcypher. One day, the voice of Vyrn
broke through my meditations.

"I dunno... She looks pretty wound up. Wouldn't she usually have dozed off by now? I'm tellin'
ya—something's going on!"
He was livelier than ever. Perfect.
"You shouldn't push yourself too hard, Narmaya!"
And sweet, tender Lyria. Yes... this was how things should be.

I cracked open my eyes and stole a hopeful glance at . But on that kind face, I could
read only worry and distress. I wanted nothing more than to comfort my darling...

I cracked open my eyes and stole a hopeful glance at . But on that kind face, I could
read only worry and distress. I wanted nothing more than to comfort my darling...
No. I was acting for their sakes.

I had already come so far. If I could just hold to my path a little longer... Make the skies a little
safer... Then I could go back to being their big sister.
I needed more strength. I needed to be worthy of this family.

The crew of the Grandcypher was powerful. But in the end, we were only small people in a vast
sky filled with endless dangers.
If I didn't get stronger, one day, that sky would engulf us.
I had to protect them. I could protect them...
All I was lacking was time.
I couldn't believe it.

I rushed back to Siero after every mission, but that day,  had dropped by without my
knowledge and taken up a request. A particularly treacherous one.
It was careless to think that Siero would reserve every single dangerous job for me.
"Aw, the Grandcypher crew's more than capable of handling it!"
"Aw, the Grandcypher crew's more than capable of handling it!"

Couldn't she see? The universe worked in dark and mysterious ways. Their lives were always in
danger!

If I allowed monsters to wander free through the skies, their rot would continue to seep until
I—just one lonely figure—could no longer hold back the tide.

I had to hunt them all down. There was not a moment to lose. I had to cut down the root of evil so
it could never spread again.
I would not kill out of malice, nor did I seek meaningless violence.

But when weighing the lives of my loved ones against the lives of these beasts... The answer was
clear.
As long as their threat persisted across the skies, the crew would never truly be safe.
And so I would wield my blade to protect the crew and the helpless.
For , I would become the harbinger of death.
Everything is for the captain. My captain. My dearest .
Everything is for the captain. My captain. My dearest .
I would kill. And kill and kill and kill.
Every. Last. Threat.
I found the largest known monster's den in this skydom and began my hunt.
"Die. For the sake of the skies... and ."
"Die. For the sake of the skies... and ."
My blade cut through flesh and bone.
Again. Again. Again, and again.
And soon, time lost all meaning. How long was I there? Perhaps three... or even four days.
My grip went numb. My vision blurred. My body grew heavy.
But I couldn't stop... Not here.
With these hands, I would deliver my loved ones...
Even if it meant seeping them in blood.
Next is 979...
I must stay strong... for !
I must... destroy every threat...
They must all be... eliminated...
Every... last... one!
My hands have gone numb...
But even in death... my sword and I are one.
Out of my sight.
To see me is to see death.
There's more above me. I can feel it!
Here.
You have breathed your last.
I will take your life... Even if it costs me mine!
I must... protect... ...
You're... finished...
1,000! I finally... did it...
Wait... There's more of them?
I-Impossible...
My body had reached its limit.

I had managed to fend off countless hordes of monsters. But more kept creeping from the
shadows.

I summoned the last of my strength for one final swing. Then my sword clattered to the ground.
Darkness.
Monsters began to close in, claws drawn, ready to kill.
I closed my eyes, waiting for it all to end.
But before my mind could fade into darkness, I was roused by a brilliant flash.
"Narmaya!"
"Narmayaaaa!"
Cap... tain?
Cap... tain?
"Let's get you out of here, quickly!"
"You had us worried, you know!"
Vyrn... Lyria too?
took my hand. But I couldn't leave yet. I had to finish the job.
"Narmaya... I'm so sorry we didn't notice what you were going through sooner..."
My heart plunged. I should've been the one apologizing. I was the one who failed.
Gently, I tried to withdraw my fingers from 's.

"We heard it all from Siero! Can't believe she's been givin' you all the hard jobs. You were doin' it
to protect us, right?"

I parted my lips. They needed to understand that it wasn't Siero's fault. That I brought this all on
myself. But my arid throat could not push out a voice.
After a moment of silence,  pressed down on my hand.

"Narmaya... I want to protect those closest to me, same as you. So if something's on your mind,
don't keep it to yourself. We're here for you."

"Narmaya... I want to protect those closest to me, same as you. So if something's on your mind,
don't keep it to yourself. We're here for you."
And just like that, I was overcome with the emotions I had tried so hard to suppress.
How could I have been so blind?

Not a single one of us could protect the crew. But that's okay. Because all of us could protect each
other. The whole is greater than its parts.
's grip was firm, and led me blinking into the sunlight.

There, I saw worry etched into the faces of the crew. I realized that, by putting myself in harm's
way, I hurt those who cared for me.
Those who loved me. Those I wanted to spend my days with—now and forever.
But the course I had been following could only lead to isolation.

still hadn't let go of my hand. Though the grip of those calloused fingers was firm, I felt
a gentle kindness in their warmth.
"! Are you hungry? I'd be more than happy to feed you... Or maybe you'd like a nap?"
"! Are you hungry? I'd be more than happy to feed you... Or maybe you'd like a nap?"
I always thought I had to be strong for my loved ones, never truly realizing they were my strength.
We supported each other. We lessened the burden of sorrow... and shared the light of joy.
"Lyria, you've got a bit of cream on your cheek. Here, let me wipe it off for you."
"Oh, um... Thank you, Narmaya."

"I'm glad Butterfly Girl's back to normal, but... is it just me, or is she laying it on even thicker than
usual?"

Vyrn was adorable, trying to play the part of the tough dragon. However, as I took him into my
arms, I thought, he shouldn't have to put on an act around me.
After all, we're family, aren't we?
On a bright, quiet day, I had a sparring match with .
I once locked myself away from the world in the pursuit of strength, training in solitude.

But I have since found that I train best with those I love around me, to lend me a guiding hand or
an encouraging voice.

held nothing back during our session. It seems I'm not the only one who has
grown stronger.

held nothing back during our session. It seems I'm not the only one who has
grown stronger.

Our blades rang bright and clear. And 's smile was a clear reminder of how far I'd
come.

After training was over, we stood for a while longer on the deck of the Grandcypher, feeling the
breeze. Above us, the azure sky was spread as far as the eye could see—its splendor too much to
take in all at once.
I felt as if I would be consumed by the sky itself, and grasped 's hand.
In that moment of peace, I swore that I would keep learning and growing...
Not alone, but together with those I love.
